text: is highly unusual for a government
adviser even one as influential as
Dominic Cummings to be in the spotlight
to this degree is raise questions once
again about the extent of his power and
to what extent Boris Johnson relies on
him day to day in the running of the
government our chief political
correspondent Vicky young takes a look
at the man and his mission he's not a
cabinet minister or an MP but Dominic
Cummings is one of the most influential
people in Westminster a formidable
campaigner who challenges tradition and
never shied away from confrontation he's
brought a unique style to government and
not just in the way he dresses for years
he's fought against closer ties with the
EU making his name in 1999 when he
joined business for Stirling opposing
the UK joining the euro working for the
Education Secretary Michael Gove 10
years later
mr. Cummings blamed the teaching unions
for low standards there were run-ins
with colleagues and stated Cameron
reportedly called him a career
psychopath it was the EU referendum that
brought Boris Johnson and Dominic
Cummings into the same team the former
was the front man mr. [ __ ] is
credited with the winning strategy it's
a formula they've tried to recreate in
government
mr. Cummings came in with ambitious
plans to reform what he called a broken
political system the civil service was
criticised advisors sacked and cabinet
ministers driven out if they didn't like
it the Conservatives were soon back in
campaign mode a winter general election
called to break the parliamentary
deadlock
the message was simple and ultimately
successful
the emphatic election victory gave mr.
Cummings a chance to put long-held ideas
into practice investment in science and
technology and in areas of the UK that
had been neglected for years in a blog
he urged weirdos and misfits to come and
work for him this all attracted a lot of
media attention and he never did much to
deflect it told you I think PJ masks are
the people we need on the job Boris
Johnson is certainly going to
extraordinary lengths to defend his
advisor
that's because Dominic Cummings is at
the heart of every decision made here he
doesn't always get his way but he's
brimming with ideas and vision there are
flaws too and many are not remotely
surprised that this abrasive character
has ended up in the eye of the storm as
long as mr. Cummings stays in Downing
Street Westminster politics will be
unpredictable Viki young BBC news well
for many today the events in Westminster
would understandably be the last thing
on their minds on a sunny Bank Holiday
Monday but much of the criticism of mr.
Cummings in recent days has come from
the perception that he bizarre being his
own set of rules and like tens of
millions of others staying at home as
instructed by the government our
reporter Fiona trot has been to Whitley
Bay in Northumbria to test opinion there
lockdown on the southeast coast hundreds
of people enjoying the sunshine at
southend-on-sea it looks like a bank
holiday before the pandemic in North
Wales are very different scene at
cranberries there people can only travel
when necessary
this was Aberdeen in Scotland today and
Portrush in Northern Ireland where
people are still being encouraged to
stay at home in the northeast of England
this has been a Whitley Bay's busiest
day during lockdown
see most people are beaches all sorts of
distances the local council says Dominic
Cummings visit to the Northeast has made
it harder for them to enforce the rules
we have to get the message out of that
we are still on lockdown
we still have sorted this a measure
enforce Boris needs to make a quick
actions now here on the promenade many
say their behavior hasn't changed but
their trust in government has it's not
right and there's rules that need to be
in place but hey so you should follow
them but if he's doing it then I do
think some people may look at that and
think well if somebody like him is doing
it then we'll change what we're doing it
has made me change my mind my tactics
I'm still alert and careful
everyone is had childcare issues every
once with small children
it feels hypocritical it feels arrogant
this ice-cream Shack is doing what it
can to keep people apart especially when
the wait feels long luciano de mio is
eagerly awaiting the next steps
responsible relaxation of the rules is
vital for towns like witchly Bay we're
fortunate enough to rely on the takeaway
our businesses geared up as well to be
able to take away obviously we do they
take away ice creams and teas and
coffees but we also well known for

oven back on
we'd like to get customers back into the

and it's time to get back to work many
traders want a return to this but during
the pandemic it feels uncomfortable for
some following government guidelines and
following your instinct on a sunny bank
holiday is a difficult balance to strike
Fiona trot BBC news
